>TO HUME LOGAN:
> Thompson had just been delving into the existential tracts of Jean-Paul Sartre when Logan, a Louisville friend and fellow Athenaeum Literary Association cohort, wrote asking for some career advice.
> April 22, 1958
> 57 Perry Street
> New York City
Dear Hume,

You ask advice: ah, what a very human and very dangerous thing to do! For to give advice to a man who asks what to do with his life implies something very close to egomania. To presume to point a man to the right and ultimate goal—to point with a trembling finger in the RIGHT direction—is something only a fool would take upon himself.

I am not a fool, but I respect your sincerity in asking my advice. I ask you though, in listening to what I say, to remember that all advice can only be a product of the ma who gives it. What is truth to one may be disaster to another. I do not see life through your eyes, nor you through mine. If I were to attempt to give you specific advice, it would be too much like the blind leading the blind.

> “To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether ’tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles.…”
> (Shakespeare)

And indeed, that IS the question: whether to float with the tide, or to swim for a goal. It is a choice we must all make—consciously or unconsciously—at one time in our lives. So few people understand this! Think of any decision you’ve ever made which had a bearing on your future: I may be wrong, but I don’t see how it could have been anything but a choice—however indirect—between the two things I’ve mentioned: the floating or the swimming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21495253
But why not float if you have no goal? That is another question. It is unquestionably better to enjoy the floating than to swim in uncertainty. So how does a man find a goal? Not a castle in the stars, but a real and tangible thing. How can a man be sure he’s not after the “big rock candy mountain,” the enticing sugar-candy goal that has little taste and no substance?

The answer—and, in a sense, the tragedy of life—is that we seek to understand the goal and not the man. We set up a goal which demands of us certain things: and we do these things. We adjust to the demands of a concept which CANNOT be valid. When you were young, let us say that you wanted to be a fireman. I feel reasonably safe in saying that you no longer want to be a fireman. Why? Because your perspective has changed. It’s not the fireman who has changed, but you. Every man is the sum total of his reactions to experience. As your experiences differ and multiply, you become a different man, and hence your perspective changes. This goes on and on. Every reaction is a learning process; every significant experience alters your perspective.

So it would seem foolish, would it not, to adjust our lives to the demands of a goal we see from a different angle every day? How could we ever hope to accomplish anything other than galloping neurosis?

The answer, then, must not deal with goals at all, or not with tangible goals, anyway. It would take reams of paper to develop this subject to fulfillment. God only knows how many books have been written on “the meaning of man” and that sort of thing, and god only knows how many people have pondered the subject. (I use the term “god only knows” purely as an expression.) There’s very little sense in my trying to give it up to you in the proverbial nutshell, because I’m the first to admit my absolute lack of qualifications for reducing the meaning of life to one or two paragraphs.

I’m going to steer clear of the word “existentialism,” but you might keep it in mind as a key of sorts. You might also try something called Being and Nothingness by Jean-Paul Sartre, and another little thing called Existentialism: From Dostoyevsky to Sartre.12 These are merely suggestions. If you’re genuinely satisfied with what you are and what you’re doing, then give those books a wide berth. (Let sleeping dogs lie.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21495257
But back to the answer. As I said, to put our faith in tangible goals would seem to be, at best, unwise. So we do not strive to be firemen, we do not strive to be bankers, nor policemen, nor doctors. WE STRIVE TO BE OURSELVES.

But don’t misunderstand me. I don’t mean that we can’t BE firemen, bankers, or doctors—but that we must make the goal conform to the individual, rather than make the individual conform to the goal. In every man, heredity and environment have combined to produce a creature of certain abilities and desires—including a deeply ingrained need to function in such a way that his life will be MEANINGFUL. A man has to BE something; he has to matter.

As I see it then, the formula runs something like this: a man must choose a path which will let his ABILITIES function at maximum efficiency toward the gratification of his DESIRES. In doing this, he is fulfilling a need (giving himself identity by functioning in a set pattern toward a set goal) he avoids frustrating his potential (choosing a path which puts no limit on his self-development), and he avoids the terror of seeing his goal wilt or lose its charm as he draws closer to it (rather than bending himself to meet the demands of that which he seeks, he has bent his goal to conform to his own abilities and desires).

In short, he has not dedicated his life to reaching a pre-defined goal, but he has rather chosen a way of life he KNOWS he will enjoy. The goal is absolutely secondary: it is the functioning toward the goal which is important. And it seems almost ridiculous to say that a man MUST function in a pattern of his own choosing; for to let another man define your own goals is to give up one of the most meaningful aspects of life—the definitive act of will which makes a man an individual.

Let’s assume that you think you have a choice of eight paths to follow (all pre-defined paths, of course). And let’s assume that you can’t see any real purpose in any of the eight. THEN—and here is the essence of all I’ve said-you MUST FIND A NINTH PATH.

Naturally, it isn’t as easy as it sounds. You’ve lived a relatively narrow life, a vertical rather than a horizontal existence. So it isn’t any too difficult to understand why you seem to feel the way you do. But a man who procrastinates in his CHOOSING will inevitably have his choice made for him by circumstance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21495262
So if you now number yourself among the disenchanted, then you have no choice but to accept things as they are, or to seriously seek something else. But beware of looking for goals: look for a way of life. Decide how you want to live and then see what you can do to make a living WITHIN that way of life.

But you say, “I don’t know where to look; I don’t know what to look for.” And there’s the crux. Is it worth giving up what I have to look for something better? I don’t know—is it? Who can make that decision but you? But even by DECIDING TO LOOK, you go a long way toward making the choice.

If I don’t call this to a halt, I’m going to find myself writing a book. I hope it’s not as confusing as it looks at first glance. Keep in mind, of course, that this is MY WAY of looking at things. I happen to think that it’s pretty generally applicable, but you may not. Each of us has to create our own credo—this merely happens to be mine.

If any part of it doesn’t seem to make sense, by all means call it to my attention. I’m not trying to send you out “on the road” in search of Valhalla, but merely pointing out that it is not necessary to accept the choices handed down to you by life as you know it. There is more to it than that—no one HAS to do something he doesn’t want to do for the rest of his life. But then again, if that’s what you wind up doing, by all means convince yourself that you HAD to do it. You’ll have lots of company.

And that’s it for now. Until I hear from you again, I remain,
your friend …
Hunter

>TO WILLIAM J. KENNEDY:
>A few months earlier William Kennedy had left San Juan for upstate New York to work part-time for the Albany Times-Union while writing fiction. Thompson wrote him this letter the day JFK was assassinated in Dallas, using—for perhaps the first time—the phrase “fear and loathing,” to describe his horror at the tragedy.
>November 22, 1963
>Woody Creek

I am tired enough to sleep here in this chair, but I have to be in town at 8:30 when Western Union opens, so what the hell. Besides, I am afraid to sleep for fear of what I might learn when I wake up. There is no human being within 500 miles to whom I can communicate anything—much less the fear and loathing that is on me after today’s murder. God knows I might go mad for lack of talk. I have become like a psychotic sphinx—I want to kill because I can’t talk.

I suppose you will say the rotten murder has no meaning for a true writer of fiction, and that the “real artists” in the “little magazines” are above such temporal things. I wish I could agree, but in fact I think that what happened today is far more meaningful than the entire contents of the “little magazines” for the past 20 years. And the next 20, if we get that far.

We now enter the era of the shitrain, President Johnson and the hardening of the arteries. Neither your children nor mine will ever be able to grasp what Gatsby was after. No more of that. You misunderstand it, of course, peeling back only the first and most obvious layer. Take your “realism” to the garbage dump. Or the “little magazines.” They are like a man who goes into a phone booth to pull his pod. Nada, nada.

The killing has put me in a state of shock. The rage is trebled. I was not prepared at this time for the death of hope, but here it is. Ignore it at your peril. I have written Semonin, that cheap book-store Marxist, that he had better tell his boys to buy bullets. And forget the dialectic. This is the end of reason, the dirtiest hour in our time. I mean to come down from the hills and enter the fray. Tomorrow a cabled job request to The Reporter. Failing that, the Observer. Beyond that, god knows, but it will have to be something. From now until the 1964 elections every man with balls should be on the firing line. The vote will be the most critical in the history of man. No matter what, today is the end of an era. No more fair play. From now on it is dirty pool and judo in the clinches. The savage nuts have shattered the great myth of American decency. They can count me in—I feel ready for a dirty game.

Fiction is dead. Mailer is an antique curiosity. The stakes are now too high and the time too short. What, O what, does Eudora Welty have to say? Fuck that crowd. The only hope now is to swing hard with the right hand, while hanging onto sanity with the left. Politics will become a cockfight and reason will go by the boards. There will have to be somebody to carry the flag.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21490980
>>21492072
Mathematics was still weak in Kant’s time. A modern mathematician (or even an undergrad) would laugh at his proofs of the a prioricity of space, for instance, which says that space as intuition is a priori since it is needed to represent something outside of us (ignoring the absolute massive possible types of spaces that could support this structure, hell even a topology would be sufficient, you don’t need euclidean space). This is why Kant got refuted as soon as science started bringing non-euclidean spaces, and more general spaces, into if’s toolkit.

As for logic, the means by which we get numbers from the categories of quantity is unclear because the underlying logical forms of judgment weren’t fully clear. The specific mechanics of how they interacted was still largely unknown and the forms were destroyed by the development of logic by Frege in logical systems, which rigorously defined everything as part of a formal system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21490980
>Kantheads - how does Kant go from plurality to discrete numbers? There doesn't seem to be anything in the categories that would allow the understanding to perceive specifically 3 of anything.
In his Critique of Pure Reason, Immanuel Kant argues that the understanding, or the human capacity for cognition, is structured by categories that allow the mind to make sense of sensory experience. These categories include quantity, which is the category of unity and plurality. Kant argues that the understanding is able to perceive and think about quantities, including discrete numbers, because it is structured to do so.

Kant suggests that the understanding is able to perceive discrete numbers because it is able to perceive units, or individual objects, and to count them. The understanding is able to perceive units as distinct from one another because it is structured to recognize the difference between unity (one) and plurality (more than one). From this starting point, the understanding is able to count individual units and to perceive specific quantities, such as three of something.

It is worth noting that Kant's theory of the categories of the understanding is complex and nuanced, and there is more to his argument about how the understanding is able to perceive quantities and discrete numbers than can be summarized in a short answer. If you are interested in learning more about Kant's philosophy, it may be helpful to read his Critique of Pure Reason or to seek out additional resources on his ideas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21495632
You're confused and thinking that Space time (really only space) is purely external and thus only of use for synthetic concepts, whereas it's pure and stands on an equal level to all possible cognitions. The question you're asking is basically transcendent: why is multiplicitous space in conformity with the categories (beyond the fact that we couldn't tell if it weren't beyond this)? This is not a question Kant can answer because he doesn't respect it: our
pure sensibility is attuned to the categories because it is. Attempting to draw a active causal relationship between the pure logical categories and our views of space time is how you get Heidegger.

You get number from space (and only space; I didn't make this clear) pure a priori because our pure sensibility is by divine fiat harmonised with our categories. This is important: our pure sensibility is created CONCURRENTLY to our pure categories: there is NO mutual interaction whereby one defines the other (I.E. categories > sensibility). Now, there COULD'VE been such an interaction (theoretically, not in the Kantian framework as made)—this being Schopenhauer's view—where the categories come first and inform our pure sensibility, but this would frustrate the way Kant specifically derives number. We would have the categories as a fixed object whilst our sensibility is constantly moving (like Bergson, in fact) whereas we'd need to have our categories move alongside our sensibility ala Hegel/Heidegger to then produce correctly quantifying numbers.

To reiterate:pure space intuition is part of our internal cognitions naturally, even the analytic ones, as it's part of our pure sensibility, which can only exist SUPPOSING the external world to which it's reconciled in Kant's dialectic, but it isn't immediately necessary, and parts of it, number, can be used analytically, though only because those numbers WILL then conform to space conditions. A point I failed to make salient is that our time is imposed on the world, and is thus immanent, whilst space is 'external'. If space were immanent like time then we wouldn't be able to think in 'pure' mathematics because 'pure' maths would necessarily be as spatial as geometry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21495235
The annoying answer is Aristotle, Descartes, Kant, Hegel and Husserl.
If you feel well-versed enough in philosophical history to take him on (he is a philosopher's philosopher, and can mostly be appreciated for his revolutions if you know what he is departing from), you can start with Being and Time, or, for an easier beginning, The Concept of the History of Time, which is a lecture series from 1925, covering much of the same territory, but delivered as a lecture, and hence, not as wilfully obtuse as Being and Time is occasionally.

Do not be afraid to engage with secondary literature, but be aware that secondary literature on Heidegger will usually emphasize different strains of his thought, and you may end up with reconstructed versions of him that are incompatible with each other - case in point would be much of the early french reception, which emphasized the existentialist aspects of his thought, nearly turning him into a secular Kierkegaard, against the american reception, which emphasized the pragmatist and structural aspects of his thought, nearly turning him into a reloaded Pierce. People will surely recommend that you read Dreyfus or watch his lectures, and he is popular for a reason - he is very good at making Heidegger understandable - but keep in mind that he is the father of the american pragmatist interpretation, and does not at all provide the whole story.

If you start with History of the Concept of Time, move on to Being and Time - I would recommend this thorough approach if you want to deeply understand him - the repetitions in the two works are slightly different, and hence, highly instructive. If you start with Being and Time, move onto The Basic Problems of Phenomenology, which moves on further from themes in Being and Time. Lastly, the Fundamental Concepts of Metaphysics, which mark the beginning of the infamous turn, Kehre.

This progression is necessary for deep understanding of him. If that is not what you want, just reading Being and Time with a bunch of secondary literature should work well enough for you to somewhat understand his place and role in the history of philosophy. I believe this progression is likewise necessary if you want to engage with the late Heidegger in any serious manner. Much of what is often derided as mysticism in his later works presents in a different light when read via the same progression of thought he himself went through.

posts.com:
Aquinas assumes that there are forms of knowledge above human discursive reason, because in addition to being an Aristotelian in terms of his system and basic concepts he is also a Platonist and follows Pseudo-Dionysius (a Neoplatonist) in many things relating to cosmology and supra-mundane reality. Discursive reason can and essentially must reveal concepts like "unmoved mover" to us, as these are perfectly logically consequent - any person with a normally functioning reason can understand the logical argument for the necessity of an unmoved mover, and the paradoxicality of other possibilities, like an infinite regress of causes. But reason cannot give us direct knowledge of God by itself. It can only lead us to the threshold by clarifying our conception of the world, in a sense creating the "space" in which other forms of knowledge (revelation, faith, mystical insight) will reveal God directly to our extra-discursive faculties.

Aquinas doesn't derive the personal, historically acting, eschatological God of the Bible from reason, he shows how reason is limited, and at its most purified, it basically calls out for higher forms of knowledge like intellectual intuition and revelation. He's a bit like a Kantian in that way, except instead of scepticism about knowledge of the noumenal, he justifies faith (pistis) which attunes us to the esoteric knowledge embedded in revelation, as well as forms of knowledge other than discursive knowledge for special and fortunate individuals.

>>21489541
One of the necessary characteristics of God is ultimacy, i.e. He or It has to be the final entity from which all other entities derive or on which they all depend, and (in many ways) to which they all tend or are oriented. "Higher dimensional beings" are already countenanced in Aquinas and in Pseudo-Dionysius, because Neoplatonism had them as well, they are just angels and sometimes personified hypostases. But they don't have the character of ultimacy. They can be metaphysically grounding from the perspective of beings subordinate to them and reliant on them, but if they aren't causa sui (cause of themselves), they don't stop the causal regress and explain reality. Likewise they can be extremely powerful but if they aren't all-creating it is basically meaningless. One can always just posit an even higher dimensional being as their master or creator, and so on in the same causal regress.

The point is to stop the regress. To do that you need to posit something that transcends finite being in such a way that it itself is not even a being (because it is logically of the nature of being to be determined in some way), which is paradoxical from the perspective of discursive knowledge and, possibly, even of angelic knowledge. Hence God is in a sense paradoxical and miraculous, a mystery in the full and classical sense of the term, and can only be accessed through His miraculous (and discursively equally inexplicable) choice to reveal Himself, to intervene in history in the form of Christ, etc. The only way to describe such a being is through negative theology, which was established in the Christian tradition by Pseudo-Dionysius using Neoplatonic categories, but ultimately going back to Philo Iudaeus and the Alexandrian school's approach to reconciling the mysteries of scripture with reason.

Just like in Aquinas' philosophy, ancient Greek reason basically burned itself out in its attempt at self-grounding, it had fizzled out in mutually contradictory but mutually overlapping and totally unsatisfying metaphysical schemes like the Stoics'.

>>21489608
>1. Why do we need to stop the regress? Our reality could be a simulation inside a reality with different rules.
Said reality would have the same question as to its ultimacy, its own cause. From the premise "everything has its cause" we have two options regarding an an indefinite search "up" the chain of causes: an infinite regress or a form of cause that is not itself an effect (a causa sui, cause of itself), stopping the regress. The question why we should prefer one to the other is as old as Plato. If you want to read or listen to an intelligent conversation about it, listen to the Copleston vs. Russell radio debate, as they touch on it and are baffled by each other's positions. If you want a very difficult but comprehensive treatment of the subject, read Schopenhauer's Fourfold Root of the Principle of Sufficient Reason or Nicholas of Cusa's Learned Ignorance.

>2. Why is a prime mover the God of the Bible and not just some rando?
A rando (i.e., a contingent being) that is not God would re-open the question as to the source of its own contingency, determinacy, and finitude - of its cause.

A rando that is God would still have to satisfy certain logical criteria, first and foremost ultimacy. Because Aquinas is in the Platonic and Aristotelian traditions, both of which take the highest goodness to be a self-evident quality of the highest being (the most actual, most real thing is also the best thing), partly as a means of explaining why things change and attain structure at all (because it is "better" to have structure and tend toward "perfection"), needs God to satisfy the logical criterion of being the highest good, basically Plato's True, Good, and Beautiful. If you deny the ontological reality of good (and thus of the better being higher than the worse), you are burdened with explaining why a cold indifferent highest principle would do anything at all, why chaos doesn't reign instead of order, etc. A purely material first principle is just as paradoxical as a miraculously and transcendently good first principle, if not more.

If you're asking why Aquinas thinks we should believe in the Christian God of the Christian scriptures in particular, that doesn't come from rational deductions but from faith (pistis), which itself can be rationally justified as a necessary aspect of the fully actualized human being in Aquinas' view. But ultimately only the act of faith itself can reveal the supra-rational truth of Christian scripture. Ultimately Aquinas can't do much to convince a committed Muslim or Jew that Christianity is the right one and not his. Conviction about such matters takes place at a different level, including the presence of the Holy Spirit in one through grace and faith, esoteric symbology directly revealing the mystical truth of the Trinity to contemplatives, mystical union with God, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21490090
Yes, but we CAN know some limited things about those realities based on logic, is Aquinas' point, since he is a metaphysical realist regarding knowledge. Logic can at least establish the limits of what is thinkable tautologically: If we assume that reality is not an infinite regress, but must have an ultimate stopping point, then the one thing we DO know about whatever being is at the end of the chain is that it is at the end of the chain. We can make similar deductions about any contingent being: If we establish that all contingency is "creaturely," then by definition any contingent being (a giant or a simulation for example) must be creaturely.

The few things we can say about God logically are that he must be there to terminate the regress (if this premise is accepted, and most people do accept it to some degree or another), and that his being must be of a kind that is beyond the being to which we are accustomed, since the being to which we are accustomed is caused, determined being, and we are looking for an entity that could explain all of it, not just another example of it.

Of course you could say this is all just our "local" logic, and higher realities could have different logics. This is basically the Kantian position, namely, that one can't attribute the concepts in one's mind to reality itself, or see them as reflections or microcosmic versions of reality's or God's own reasoning, like the medieval scholastics and the Cartesians (including Spinoza and Leibniz) did. But this opens up a whole host of paradoxes too, and eventually dissolves into complete solipsism if pushed far enough. That's why Kant's successors tried to find a way to argue from certain principles (like that our reason, being part of reality, must in some way reflect and participate in reality) to break out of the soap bubble Kant trapped us in, and back out into some kind of metaphysical realism. Things get complicated beyond that point.

>The alternative is simply being a skeptic.
Everybody has ontological commitments whether they like it or not. An attempt to be totally neutral presumes that there is a universal, pre-determined neutral position, which would be non-neutral. This has de facto resulted in the "disenchantment of the world" and the spread of a vulgar materialism and vulgar hedonistic individualism and technology worship, which aren't neutral at all, more like leftover remnants of dead Enlightenment philosophies.

Sure, basically Aristotle defines most objects as having both essence (form) and existence. The idea is that existence is some sort of raw, unrealized potentiality (this is why you often hear classical theists referring to God as 'pure actuality'), and form is the restrictive aspect that gives that potentiality a recognizable organization. >>21490185
You have it around the wrong way, but you're close to the proper answer, regardless. You've actually touched upon one of the more interesting consequences of Aristotelian philosophy, in particular the interrelation of potency and act (even though, as I said, you have the relationship around the wrong way). I have two recommendations on exactly this topic, because I find it very interesting myself. The first, for a basic rundown of why what you've said is not quite correct, is Edward Feser's "Scholastic Metaphysics", and the specific chapter/section on the Potency/Act distinction. The second is René Guénon's book "Reign of Quantity", in the chapter titled, "Materia Signata Quantitate", which further elaborates upon this exact distinction in a more profound manner (alternatively you could go straight to Aquinas in his own writings on the nature of matter, unfortunately it is a harder read).

To give a brief rundown myself, what this means is that "matter", and more generally "potency" (as matter is a specific kind of restriction and therefore a species of potency, which Aquinas defines as a limitation through quantity*), is the specific limiting condition of any act. Act, which is in this context is used interchangeably with "form" (or "substantial form"), taken by itself is actually infinite and unlimited, and is only limited by its being embodied either in matter, or more generally in any kind of potentiality or potency. The stock example here is the perfect circle, which in its essence is both Infinite and One, and is only ever limited, by potency, when it takes on a material instantiation, whether that instantiation is only imaginary (when we imagine or visualize a circle) or when we see one created elsewhere. The conclusion from this example is that any form or act is limited by the matter which it is conceived in. Hence why it is said that God is "actus purus" (Pure Act), and is devoid of any potentiality or potency (except for active potencies, which are quite different to passive potencies, which are what was referred to earlier). In any case, to say that "God has no form" is halfway erroneous at the very least; at the very least it depends on what sense you're giving to the term "form." God obviously has no spatial shape, or anything similarly gross.

*Therefore Aquinas's Materia Secunda, the matter of our world, is of the essence of quantitative number in discrete mode. Guénon goes on to make the point that continuous quantity (eg in geometric representation) is more fully act than the former.

>Thomistic* point of view.
This is incorrect: in Metaphysics Aristotle is direct in his statement that immaterial substance is the prime question of metaphysics/theology (material substance being the subject of physics).
>the Unmoved Movers
The Unmoved Movers do not possess matter, and are therefore immaterial according to Aristotle's scheme. The first few chapters of De Caelo clarify this idea. Aristotle argues pure circular motion is the only motion capable of existing without matter, because there is no true contrary to circular motion (he gives arguments as to why clockwise, counterclockwise and rectilinear motion are not proper contraries, whether you accept them is a different question), and only things with contraries can be composed of matter (a corollary of Aristotle's general hylomorphism). And even if we forget about how weak Aristotle's argument is for the multiple movers, it is still basically in line with Aquinas's statements about the metaphysical status of Angels (as immaterial beings which are not pure act) when taken apart from its arguments. What you're likely confused about is the celestial beings existing in aether according to Aristotle, which is (again as demonstrated in De Caelo) immaterial substance, and does not admit of generation and corruption for the previously mentioned reason.

Wikipedia is not a valid reference, unfortunately.

An element, in common and even technical parlance, is something which makes up something else, is matter for something else. But aether neither is nor has matter, because it is indestructible (and Aristotle goes to pains in the same work to show that the regular elements are not indestructible like the atomists claimed). Aether is, as stated by Aristotle, a "body" which is more primary than the other bodies (which are proper elements, like fire and water), because it A) possesses no matter; and therefore B) is indestructible and non-generable, not subject to any form of alteration in the technical Aristotelian sense; C) possesses no weight (it is neither light nor heavy), and apart from not being nor possessing matter, D) is more pure than the other bodies because circular motion is more perfect than rectilinear motion.

Seeing as you're desperate to pull out secondary sources, as though they vouchsafe you, without even giving a relevant direct statement from Aristotle, I will do the hard work for you and close this discussion now (from De Caelo of course):
>These premises clearly show that there is in nature some substance other than the formation we know, prior to them all and more divine than they. 269a30
>On all these grounds, therefore, we may infer with confidence that there is something beyond the bodies that are about us on this earth, different and separate from them; and that the superior glory of its nature is proportionate to its distance from this world of ours. 269b15
>In consequence of what has been said, in part by way of assumption and in part by way of proof, it is clear that not every body possesses lightness or heaviness. [...] The body, then, that moves in a circle [aether] cannot possibly possess either heaviness or lightness. [...] Secondly, that it cannot possibly move in the way of locomotion by being forced violently aside in an upward or downward direction. For neither naturally nor unnaturally can it move with any other motion but its own, either itself or any part of it. 269b - 270a
>It is equally reasonable to assume that this body will be ungenerated and indestructible and exempt from increase and alteration, since everything that comes to be comes into being from its contrary and in some substrate [matter], and passes away likewise in a substrate by the action of the contrary into the contrary, as we explained in our opening discussions. Now the motions of contrary are contrary. If then this body can have no contrary, because there can be no contrary motion to hte circular, nature seems justly to have exempted from contraries the body which was to be ungenerated and indestructible. For it is in contraries [matter] that generation and decay subsist. 270a 15-25.

In Aristotle's scheme, this means it is without matter because only matter possesses, or is, substratum (which is why all of the other elements, like fire and water, can convert between each other according to Aristotle when they dissolve into less substantial forms; because they are composites of form, eg fire, and matter, which has no specific properties, unless it is proximate matter). This ties into a broader point which was made by Aquinas and not Aristotle, that matter's "defining feature", if it must be said to have one, is signata quantitate, or principium individuationis. It individuates material substances which have the same substantial form, which is its only significance, hence why in the Books Delta and Zeta of Metaphysics, Aristotle himself rightly points out that matter is the least substantial of all kinds of being, even though it is still relevant to our kind of existence and so not wholly unimportant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I haven’t read much of her poetry, but I was touched deeply by The Bell Jar. I can definitely understand why some, even many, dislike it or find it whiny. It’s definitely not perfect or some masterpiece but it is very honest. I have a lot of bipolar family members on one side, and I didn’t come out unscathed genetically. The Bell Jar really captured and articulated a lot of that experience in a way I had been grasping for but had failed to before I read it. Like when you have it all and it still comes down on you and you don’t even really understand why you itch to let go off the wheel going over a bridge because there’s nothing wrong in your life. And the only thing to live for is the fog lifting but it’s been so long since you last felt it you can’t be sure it ever really happened and you didn’t imagine it.

Not many books touched me as deeply as it did, but it was for personal reasons more than its artistry. Though it did have some great, surprising descriptions in there.

>“The Bell Jar” is a fictionalized account of Plath’s own breakdown and shock therapy and suicide attempt in 1953, and Plath did not want the originals of her unlovely characters—particularly her mother—to read the book. Esther’s mother is rendered with deft mercilessness. “My mother took care never to tell me to do anything,” Esther caustically observes. “She would only reason with me sweetly, like one intelligent mature person with another.” Also examined and found wanting in every respect are, among others, Olive Higgins Prouty, the author of “Stella Dallas,” who was Plath’s benefactor (she was the sponsor of Plath’s freshman scholarship at Smith, paid for her hospitalization after her suicide attempt, and became a lifelong friend of Aurelia’s); Plath’s college boyfriend, Dick Norton; and his mother. Plath therefore published the book under the pseudonym Victoria Lucas. It came out in England in January of 1963 under that name and then, after her suicide, under her own name. (Two American publishers had turned it down.) When “The Bell Jar” was finally scheduled for publication in America, in 1971, Aurelia Plath was beside herself. In a letter to the publisher she wrote:

>Practically every character in The Bell Jar represents someone—often in caricature—whom Sylvia loved; each person had given freely of time, thought, affection, and, in one case, financial help during those agonizing six months of breakdown in 1953. . . . As this book stands by itself, it represents the basest ingratitude.

She is the first free verse poet I liked. I still remember a lot of her lines.

>Ten fingers shape a bowl for shadows.
>The clear vowels rise like balloons.
>Black sweet blood mouthfuls.
>The wet dawn inks are doing their blue dissolve.
>Stasis in darkness. / Then the substanceless blues / Pour of tor and distances.
>Cold worlds shake from the oar.

posts.name: Anonymous

https://archive.org/details/lifelettersofpet00chaiuoft

>Do not believe those who try to persuade you that composition is only a cold exercise of the intellect. The only music capable of moving and touching us is that which flows from the depths of a composer’s soul when he is stirred by inspiration. There is no doubt that even the greatest musical geniuses have sometimes worked without inspiration. This guest does not always respond to the first invitation. We must always work, and a self-respecting artist must not fold his hands on the pretext that he is not in the mood. If we wait for the mood, without endeavouring to meet it half-way, we easily become indolent and apathetic. We must be patient, and believe that inspiration will come to those who can master their disinclination.

>A few days ago I told you I was working every day without any real inspiration. Had I given way to my disinclination, undoubtedly I should have drifted into a long period of idleness. But my patience and faith did not fail me, and to-day I felt that inexplicable glow of inspiration of which I told you; thanks to which I know beforehand that whatever I write to-day will have power to make an impression, and to touch the hearts of those who hear it. I hope you will not think I am indulging in self-laudation, if I tell you that I very seldom suffer from this disinclination to work. I believe the reason for this is that I am naturally patient. I have learnt to master myself, and I am glad I have not followed in the steps of some of my Russian colleagues, who have no self-confidence and are so impatient that at the least difficulty they are ready to throw up the sponge. This is why, in spite of great gifts, they accomplish so little, and that in an amateur way.

Besides Wagner and Tchaikovsky, which other composers had essays/letters/lectures worth reading?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Carl Maria von Weber had an unfinished autobio-like novel where he described similar attitude as in op. the fragments remain untranslated i think.
Liszt also wrote about "meeting inspiration halfway", but some of his essays were ghostwritten by marie lipsius, e.g. his book about chopin.
Heuberger's and Gustav Jenner's reminiscences of Brahms describe his opposite, "cold" attitude to composition. one of them even had direct opportunity of comparison with chaikovsky's teaching methods.
hugo wolf's collected concert reviews are worth reading for entertainment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Holy shit. Just finished this. No wonder Bloom called it the best novel the 20th century.

What really struck me is how pure-hearted and beautiful this turned out to be. After reading V and GR, I assumed Pynchon was a cynical horny albeit brilliant edgelord who had no faith in human progress. (GR honestly might be the most misanthropic novel I've read.) So for him to lay out a sentimental and Quixotic tale of camaraderie and scientific progress in early America with such beauty and conviction blew me away.

The parts where Mason and Dixon go tavern hopping or discover those extraterrestrial mounds or encounter the mechanical duck radiate this purity of adventure and optimism that I've gotten from few other novels. The final chapter of part two, where Rev Cherrycoke imagines M&D extending the Line into the Atlantic and settling there forever as friends, legitimately made me cry. It was such an overwhelming aesthetic experience I ended up reading it all in a couple days.

Very curious what people think about the ending. Seeing the two settle into mundane life as industrialization takes over Europe and Dixon succumbs to illness was such a depressing comedown from the high of their mystical journey out West. And the final conversation between Mason and Ben Franklin is wrought with so much cryptic shit. Is the "Engine" Mason senilely warns Frankling about just the American continent once totally mapped and colonized? It feels like Mason is foreshadowing all of GR, namely the foreclosure of death in a corporatized technocratic security state.

Gonna let this sit with me for a while, but right now it feels like my favorite novel ever. Pynchon has such a strong and singular historical worldview it's almost contagious.

posts.com:
The problem is that you need a metaphilosophical, meta-methodological perspective to critically understand and potentially adopt any proposed metaphilosophy or meta-methodology for studying philosophy in the first place. The only way to begin is by beginning. Logicism is filled with presuppositions in how it articulates and conceives presuppositionlessness. Hermeneutics requires a hermeneutic understanding of the presuppositions and development of hermeneutics.

The best way to study is to wade in, pick a territory (like early modern political theory for instance), and master it. Then master an adjacent (either thematically or chronologically) territory, and reflect on how it has revised your perception of the first territory. Most likely you will feel that your initial understanding of the first territory was totally insufficient and blinkered, that you were seeing three-dimensional objects in two dimensions, and only now that you have mastered the aforementioned adjacent terrain can you really understand it properly. But mastery of the adjacent terrain was only possible by first "succeeding at failing" to master the initial terrain. The real noodle-scratcher comes when you realize that this process is presumably indefinite, and that a third or n+1 terrain will dialectically revise your conceptions of all the preceding terrains, and vice versa. Then the final realization is that this is an asymptotic process, a hermeneutic circle, of which one can become progressively more aware.

Wittgenstein:
>My propositions are elucidatory in this way: he who understands me finally recognizes them as senseless, when he has climbed out through them, on them, over them. (He must so to speak throw away the ladder, after he has climbed up on it.) He must surmount these propositions; then he sees the world rightly.

Beckett:
>Ever failed. No matter. Try again. Fail again. Fail better.

posts.com:
Start by doing a bit of reading on pre-philosophical thought, sometimes referred to as mythopoeic thought. The Greek myths, especially Homer and Hesiod, are a good place to start. The idea of doing this is to start to get your head around the question of what philosophical thought is, by considering how it differs from non- or pre-philosophical thought.

After that, I would go through the presocratic philosophers one at a time. Compare and contrast them with each other, and with the pre-philosophical mode of thought you are now somewhat familiar with. That done, you can move on to Plato and Aristotle. Once you've spent some serious time with them, you'll have enough of a philosophical grounding to start browsing through medieval, early modern, and modern philosophy. Philosophy is an ancient tradition, and you'll find that later thinkers are always engaging with ancient sources, even when they disagree radically with them. Almost all of the central problems of philosophy take the same basic form that they did 2,500 years ago, even if the details are different.

>ebooks can't get damaged

>no accidental page flipping
There is nothing more comfy than reading without using two hands to hold the book that no pages flip while also reading with your finger
>all books in one ereader
You don't need a shelf or anthing else. Just a small tablet sized ereader while having all of your books on it.
>you can upgrade
The best part about ebooks is that you can just buy an advanced ereader and ALL of your books profit. Remember this cheap paperback you bought? It will never look better. Ereader on the other hand can improve with so many things, from higher resolution to comfy lighting.
>all those setting
You want a bigger font? A different font? Switch stuff up from time to time? Have background lighting (NEVER EVER depends on lighting conditions!)? Have different kinds of lighting? Have a translator? Have an additional wiki? Have the option to combine reading and audiobooks?

Unironically the ONLY reason to be cautious about buying ebooks is the strange copyright laws. If you buy a book, you own it. If you buy a digital ebook, it comes with some strange legal stuff.
Sure, some countries' courts straight up said "If you bought an ebook from Amazon, and Amazon closes your account, you still have a right to read and get your bought ebook". The problem is that in buying digital movies from Amazon it's common that you sometimes lose access if the copyright deal expires. Technically if you buy an ebook and Amazon loses the rights to sell it, it can be that you won't be able to download your bought ebook again.

It's a complicated question about the "buying side" for ebooks. But if you exclusively use free ebooks and put those offline on your ereader, there is literally no downside compared to buying an expensive book.

Has anyone read this? Secular biblical academics treat NT Wright as a meme, but the man writes with extreme clarity, and the whole book has this narrative drive that makes it read like a novel.

His argument essentially boils down to:
> Paul was a zealous and well-read jew inspired by the "righteousness" of jews like Phinehas and Judas Maccabees.
>He persecuted christians before having a le trippy experience where he saw a vision of Jesus in the desert
>He believed that Jesus’ death and resurrection had fulfilled prophecies found in the OT (especially in Isaiah) This caused him to spread this new JEWISH message throughout the Roman Empire
>In conquering death, Jesus had broken the power of evil in the world, including pagan idolatry. Therefore, all were saved, Gentile or Jew.
>Most of the debate in early Christian communities centered around whether or not gentile converts had to mutilate their dicks. >Paul unequivocally said that they did NOT need to be circumcised, leading to a public spiff with Peter.
>Paul continues traveling and spreading his message in synagogues throughout the ancient near east. He constantly is seen as having too pagan of a message for the Jews (a crucified Messiah was an absurd concept); he is simultaneously seen as having too jewish of a message for the pagans, especially involving sexual ethics and kosher laws
>He is constantly beaten, betrayed, and facing death. Yet he finds inspiration in this message of Jesus before continuing his ministry.
>All of the epistles that are absolutely from Paul deal with internal church conflict. Because of this there is always a one-sided conversation from which we must infer the situation Paul is reacting to.
>Paul finds out that Rome has a church. He writes his longest letter to them, these people he’s never met and who are suspicious of him, asking for money and a place to setup shop for when he goes to Spain. (it’s funny that his most potent theological letter was substantially a fundraising circular, kek jew)

Like Paul, Wright’s book is stuck in the middle. Its historical arguments undermine its theological points, and its theological points are entirely reliant on biblical sources. He admits some of the letters are questionable, but there is virtually 0 discussion on their historicity. One of his central points was that Paul wrote Ephesians while imprisoned and that the theology present in the letter was a result of his isolation. Wright copes and says that Paul was “deliberately adopting the Asiatic style of writing” to appeal to the parishioners

This book is around 450 pages and is worth reading for people interested in theology or biblical history. It’s worth it alone to make Nietzschecucks crying up Paul le ruining christianity with moral law

Tldr; Fun and easy-to-read biography Paul’s ministry reconstructed entirely from Acts and the Epistles. Read it if you like biblical studies or Christian theology.

>>21495271
It's probably the most asked questions about the historicity of any of these figures. I can summarize some kind of consensus viewpoint , but do not take this as authoritative.

For the vast majority of ancient figures, we have very little writings from the period they lived. For many Mesopotamian kings, we have their name etched on a tablet. Other ancient figures are more or less well attested, but the point is that we know nothing about 99.99% of all humans that have ever lived. For many figures, the earliest documents that still physically exist were written hundreds of years after the events they describe.

My point is that it is not unusual that we do not have much contemporary evidence for Jesus or Paul. Getting into the 2nd and 3rd centuries we start to see much more evidence, but, as you correctly assume, the earlier the sources the better.

We have two non-Christian sources that mention Jesus, both written around 60-80 years after his death.
The jewish-roman historian Josephus mentions Jesus as
>the brother of Jesus, who was called Christ, whose name was James
The quote above is much longer, but most historians think parts of it was a later Christian forgery, although with a nucleus of truth.

Our other source comes from the Roman historian Racitus, who mentions Jesus' execution under Pontius Pilate. We do have the Pilate Stone and multiple sources mentioning Pilate, so he certainly was governor of Judah when Jesus was executed.

However, you seem to assume that the Bible itself is somehow unreliable. This makes sense, considering it is ultimately a piece of theology, but that does not mean it isn't deeply historical. There's a whole field of studies related to establishing the historical aspects of the Bible, of which there are many. It also remains the ancient text with the most copies for what that's worth.
